Proof of Proposition 1.2.15

Note that I used (i)-(viii) instead of (a)-(h) to label the statements. Everything else should be exactly the same as in the textbook.

Proposition (Basic properties of open and closed sets)

Let (X,d)(X, d)(X,d) be a metric space.

  1. Let EEE be a subset of XXX. Then EEE is open if and only if E=int⁡(E)E = \int\p{E}E=int(E). In other words, EEE is open if and only if for every x∈Ex \in Ex∈E, there exists an r>0r > 0r>0 such that B(x,r)⊆EB\p{x, r} \subseteq EB(x,r)⊆E.
  2. Let EEE be a subset of XXX. Then EEE is closed if and only if EEE contains all its adherent points. In other words, EEE is closed if and only if for every convergent sequence (xn)n=m∞\p{x_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ in EEE, the limit lim⁡n→∞xn\lim_{n\to\infty} x_nlimn→∞​xn​ of that sequence also lies in EEE.
  3. For any x0∈Xx_0 \in Xx0​∈X and r>0r > 0r>0, then the ball B(x0,r)B\p{x_0, r}B(x0​,r) is an open set. The set {x∈X | d(x,x0)≤r}\set{x \in X \st d\p{x, x_0} \leq r}{x∈X∣d(x,x0​)≤r} is a closed set. (This set is sometimes called the closed ball of radius rrr centered at x0x_0x0​.)
  4. Any singleton set {x0}\set{x_0}{x0​}, where x0∈Xx_0 \in Xx0​∈X, is automatically closed.
  5. If EEE is a subset of XXX, then EEE is open if and only if the complement X∖E≔{x∉X | x∉E}X \setminus E \coloneqq \set{x \notin X \st x \notin E}X∖E:={x∈/X∣x∈/E} is closed.
  6. If E1,…,EnE_1, \ldots, E_nE1​,…,En​ is a finite collection of open sets in XXX, then E1∩E2∩⋯∩EnE_1 \cap E_2 \cap \cdots \cap E_nE1​∩E2​∩⋯∩En​ is also open. If F1,…,FnF_1, \ldots, F_nF1​,…,Fn​ is a finite collection of closed sets in XXX, then F1∪F2∪⋯∪FnF_1 \cup F_2 \cup \cdots \cup F_nF1​∪F2​∪⋯∪Fn​ is also closed.
  7. If {Eα}α∈I\set{E_\alpha}_{\alpha \in I}{Eα​}α∈I​ is a collection of open sets in XXX (where the index set III could be finite, countable, or uncountable), then the union ⋃α∈IEα≔{x∈X | x∈Eα for some α∈I}\bigcup_{\alpha \in I} E_\alpha \coloneqq \set{x \in X \st x \in E_\alpha \text{ for some } \alpha \in I}⋃α∈I​Eα​:={x∈X∣x∈Eα​ for some α∈I} is also open. If {Fα}α∈I\set{F_\alpha}_{\alpha \in I}{Fα​}α∈I​ is a collection of closed sets in XXX, then the intersection ⋂α∈IFα≔{x∈X∣x∈Fα for all α∈I}\bigcap_{\alpha \in I} F_\alpha \coloneqq \set{x \in X \mid x \in F_\alpha \text{ for all } \alpha \in I}⋂α∈I​Fα​:={x∈X∣x∈Fα​ for all α∈I} is also closed.
  8. If EEE is any subset of XXX, then int⁡(E)\int\p{E}int(E) is the largest open set which is contained in EEE; in other words, int⁡(E)\int\p{E}int(E) is open, and given any other open set V⊆EV \subseteq EV⊆E, we have V⊆int⁡(E)V \subseteq\int\p{E}V⊆int(E). Similarly E‾\overline{E}E is the smallest closed set which contains EEE; in other words, E‾\overline{E}E is closed, and given any other closed set K⊇EK \supseteq EK⊇E, K⊇E‾K \supseteq \cl{E}K⊇E.
Proof.

  1. "  ⟹  \implies⟹"

    Assume EEE is open. By definition, this means that ∂E∩E=∅\bd{E} \cap E = \emptyset∂E∩E=∅.

    First, notice that E⊇int⁡(E)E \supseteq \int\p{E}E⊇int(E) by definition of int⁡(E)\int\p{E}int(E) (check this!). For the reverse inclusion, let x∈Ex \in Ex∈E. Recall that int⁡(E),ext⁡(E),∂E\int\p{E}, \ext\p{E}, \bd{E}int(E),ext(E),∂E partition XXX; that is, the three sets are disjoint and their union is all of XXX:

    X=int⁡(E)∪ext⁡(E)∪∂E.X = \int\p{E} \cup \ext\p{E} \cup \bd{E}.X=int(E)∪ext(E)∪∂E.

    Since x∈Ex \in Ex∈E, we know that x∉ext⁡(E)x \notin \ext\p{E}x∈/ext(E) (check this!). Because ∂E∩E=∅\bd{E} \cap E = \emptyset∂E∩E=∅ and x∈Ex \in Ex∈E, this means that x∉∂Ex \notin \bd{E}x∈/∂E. Thus, x∈int⁡(E)x \in \int\p{E}x∈int(E).

    This shows that E⊆int⁡(E)E \subseteq \int\p{E}E⊆int(E), so E=int⁡(E)E = \int\p{E}E=int(E) by double-inclusion.

    "  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

    Assume E=int⁡(E)E = \int\p{E}E=int(E). By definition, we need to check that ∂E∩E=∅\bd{E} \cap E = \emptyset∂E∩E=∅. We have

    ∂(E)∩E=∂(E)∩int⁡(E)=∅,\bd\p{E} \cap E = \bd\p{E} \cap \int\p{E} = \emptyset,∂(E)∩E=∂(E)∩int(E)=∅,

    where in the last step, we used the fact that int⁡(E),ext⁡(E),∂E\int\p{E}, \ext\p{E}, \bd{E}int(E),ext(E),∂E partition XXX.

  2. "  ⟹  \implies⟹"

    Assume EEE is closed. This means that ∂E⊆E\bd{E} \subseteq E∂E⊆E. We know that the set of adherent points of EEE satisfies E‾=E∪∂E\cl{E} = E \cup \bd{E}E=E∪∂E (this is Proposition 1.2.10 in the textbook), so because both E⊆EE \subseteq EE⊆E and ∂E⊆E\bd{E} \subseteq E∂E⊆E, their union E‾⊆E\cl{E} \subseteq EE⊆E also.

    "  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

    Assume that E‾⊆E\cl{E} \subseteq EE⊆E. By Proposition 1.2.10 again, we know E∪∂E⊆EE \cup \bd{E} \subseteq EE∪∂E⊆E. In particular, ∂E⊆E\bd{E} \subseteq E∂E⊆E, so EEE is closed by definition,

  3. By part (i), we need to show that for all y∈B(x0,r)y \in B\p{x_0, r}y∈B(x0​,r), there exists s>0s > 0s>0 such that B(y,s)⊆B(x0,r)B(y, s) \subseteq B\p{x_0, r}B(y,s)⊆B(x0​,r). (It's a little confusing, but in (i), I replaced EEE with B(x0,r)B\p{x_0, r}B(x0​,r), x0x_0x0​ with yyy, and rrr with sss.)

    Let s=r−d(x0,y)s = r - d\p{x_0, y}s=r−d(x0​,y) (draw a picture to see where I got this from). Then if z∈B(y,s)z \in B\p{y, s}z∈B(y,s),

    d(z,x)≤d(z,y)+d(y,x0)<s+d(x0,y)=r.d\p{z, x} \leq d\p{z, y} + d\p{y, x_0} < s + d\p{x_0, y} = r.d(z,x)≤d(z,y)+d(y,x0​)<s+d(x0​,y)=r.

    In other words, d(z,x0)<rd\p{z, x_0} < rd(z,x0​)<r, which means z∈B(x0,r)z \in B\p{x_0, r}z∈B(x0​,r). Thus, B(y,s)⊆B(x0,r)B\p{y, s} \subseteq B\p{x_0, r}B(y,s)⊆B(x0​,r), so B(x0,r)B\p{x_0, r}B(x0​,r) is open.

    For brevity, I will denote K(x0,r)≔{x∈X | d(x,x0)≤r}K\p{x_0, r} \coloneqq \set{x \in X \st d\p{x, x_0} \leq r}K(x0​,r):={x∈X∣d(x,x0​)≤r}. We'll use (ii): let (xn)n=m∞\p{x_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ be a sequence of elements in K(x0,r)K\p{x_0, r}K(x0​,r) which converges to x′∈Xx' \in Xx′∈X. We need to show that x′∈K(x0,r)x' \in K\p{x_0, r}x′∈K(x0​,r). Since xn∈K(x0,r)x_n \in K\p{x_0, r}xn​∈K(x0​,r), we have

    d(x′,x0)≤d(x′,xn)+d(xn,x0)≤d(x′,xn)+r.d\p{x', x_0} \leq d\p{x', x_n} + d\p{x_n, x_0} \leq d\p{x', x_n} + r.d(x′,x0​)≤d(x′,xn​)+d(xn​,x0​)≤d(x′,xn​)+r.

    Lastly, because xn→n→∞x′x_n \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} x'xn​n→∞​x′, we can send n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞ to get d(x′,x0)≤rd\p{x', x_0} \leq rd(x′,x0​)≤r.

    (I used the following fact from 131A: if an→n→∞aa_n \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} aan​n→∞​a and an≤La_n \leq Lan​≤L for all nnn, then a≤La \leq La≤L.)

  4. We'll use (ii). Let (xn)n=m∞\p{x_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ be a sequence of elements in {x0}\set{x_0}{x0​} which converges to x′∈Xx' \in Xx′∈X. Since xn∈{x0}x_n \in \set{x_0}xn​∈{x0​}, this means that xn=x0x_n = x_0xn​=x0​ for all nnn, i.e., (xn)n=m∞\p{x_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ is a constant sequence. Thus, xn→n→∞x0∈{x0}x_n \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} x_0 \in \set{x_0}xn​n→∞​x0​∈{x0​}, so {x0}\set{x_0}{x0​} is closed.

  5. "  ⟹  \implies⟹"

    Assume EEE is open. Suppose (xn)n=m∞\p{x_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ is a sequence of elements in X∖EX \setminus EX∖E which converges to x0∈Xx_0 \in Xx0​∈X. We need to show that x0∈X∖Ex_0 \in X \setminus Ex0​∈X∖E. If x0∈Ex_0 \in Ex0​∈E, then because EEE is open, there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that B(x0,r)⊆EB\p{x_0, r} \subseteq EB(x0​,r)⊆E. But because xn→n→∞x0x_n \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} x_0xn​n→∞​x0​, there exists n≥mn \geq mn≥m such that xn∈B(x0,r)x_n \in B\p{x_0, r}xn​∈B(x0​,r). This means xn∈E∩(X∖E)=∅x_n \in E \cap \p{X \setminus E} = \emptysetxn​∈E∩(X∖E)=∅, which is a contradiction.

    "  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

    Assume X∖EX \setminus EX∖E is closed. We will show that ∂E∩E=∅\bd{E} \cap E = \emptyset∂E∩E=∅. Let x0∈∂Ex_0 \in \bd{E}x0​∈∂E. By definition, this means that for all r>0r > 0r>0, we have B(x0,r)∩(X∖E)≠∅B\p{x_0, r} \cap \p{X \setminus E} \neq \emptysetB(x0​,r)∩(X∖E)=∅. But this is exactly what it means for x0∈X∖E‾=X∖Ex_0 \in \cl{X \setminus E} = X \setminus Ex0​∈X∖E​=X∖E.

  6. Let x0∈E1∩⋯∩Enx_0 \in E_1 \cap \cdots \cap E_nx0​∈E1​∩⋯∩En​. For each 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n, x0∈Eix_0 \in E_ix0​∈Ei​, so because EiE_iEi​ is open, there exists ri>0r_i > 0ri​>0 such that B(x0,ri)⊆EiB\p{x_0, r_i} \subseteq E_iB(x0​,ri​)⊆Ei​. Let r=min⁡{r1,…,rn}>0r = \min\set{r_1, \ldots, r_n} > 0r=min{r1​,…,rn​}>0 (this is where we use the fact that we have a finite intersection). Then for each 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n,

    B(x0,r)⊆B(x0,ri)⊆Ei.B\p{x_0, r} \subseteq B\p{x_0, r_i} \subseteq E_i.B(x0​,r)⊆B(x0​,ri​)⊆Ei​.

    Thus, B(x0,r)⊆E1∩⋯∩EnB\p{x_0, r} \subseteq E_1 \cap \cdots \cap E_nB(x0​,r)⊆E1​∩⋯∩En​, so E1∩⋯∩EnE_1 \cap \cdots \cap E_nE1​∩⋯∩En​ is open.

    For the second statement, we can use (v) by taking complements. Note that

    X∖(F1∪⋯∪Fn)=(X∖F1)∩⋯∩(X∖Fn).X \setminus \p{F_1 \cup \cdots \cup F_n} = \p{X \setminus F_1} \cap \cdots \cap \p{X \setminus F_n}.X∖(F1​∪⋯∪Fn​)=(X∖F1​)∩⋯∩(X∖Fn​).

    By (v), X∖F1,…,X∖FnX \setminus F_1, \ldots, X \setminus F_nX∖F1​,…,X∖Fn​ are all open sets, so the first statement (where we plug in Ei=X∖FiE_i = X \setminus F_iEi​=X∖Fi​) implies that X∖(F1∪⋯∪Fn)X \setminus \p{F_1 \cup \cdots \cup F_n}X∖(F1​∪⋯∪Fn​) is open. By (v) again, F1∪⋯∪FnF_1 \cup \cdots \cup F_nF1​∪⋯∪Fn​ is closed.

  7. Let x0∈⋃α∈IEαx_0 \in \bigcup_{\alpha \in I} E_\alphax0​∈⋃α∈I​Eα​. By definition, this means there exists α∈I\alpha \in Iα∈I such that x0∈Eαx_0 \in E_\alphax0​∈Eα​. Since this EαE_\alphaEα​ is open, there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that

    B(x0,r)⊆Eα⊆⋃α∈IEα,B\p{x_0, r} \subseteq E_\alpha \subseteq \bigcup_{\alpha \in I} E_\alpha,B(x0​,r)⊆Eα​⊆α∈I⋃​Eα​,

    so ⋃α∈IEα\bigcup_{\alpha \in I} E_\alpha⋃α∈I​Eα​ is open.

    As in the proof of (vi), we can prove the second statement by using (v) and taking complements.

    X∖⋂α∈IFα=⋃α∈I(X∖Fα)X \setminus \bigcap_{\alpha \in I} F_\alpha = \bigcup_{\alpha \in I} \p{X \setminus F_\alpha}X∖α∈I⋂​Fα​=α∈I⋃​(X∖Fα​)

    is a union of open sets, hence open by the first statement. By (v), this means ⋂α∈IFα\bigcap_{\alpha \in I} F_\alpha⋂α∈I​Fα​ is closed.

  8. First, we show that int⁡(E)\int\p{E}int(E) is open. Let x0∈int⁡(E)x_0 \in \int\p{E}x0​∈int(E) so that there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that B(x0,r)⊆EB\p{x_0, r} \subseteq EB(x0​,r)⊆E. By (iii), B(x0,r)B\p{x_0, r}B(x0​,r) is an open set, so given any y∈B(x0,r)y \in B\p{x_0, r}y∈B(x0​,r), there exists s>0s > 0s>0 so that

    B(y,s)⊆B(x0,r)⊆E,B\p{y, s} \subseteq B\p{x_0, r} \subseteq E,B(y,s)⊆B(x0​,r)⊆E,

    so y∈int⁡(E)y \in \int\p{E}y∈int(E). Thus, B(x0,r)⊆int⁡(E)B\p{x_0, r} \subseteq \int\p{E}B(x0​,r)⊆int(E), so int⁡(E)\int\p{E}int(E) is open.

    Now, assume V⊆EV \subseteq EV⊆E, where VVV is an open set. Then for any x0∈Vx_0 \in Vx0​∈V, there exists r>0r > 0r>0 so that

    B(x0,r)⊆V⊆E,B\p{x_0, r} \subseteq V \subseteq E,B(x0​,r)⊆V⊆E,

    so x0∈int⁡(E)x_0 \in \int\p{E}x0​∈int(E). Thus, V⊆int⁡(E)V \subseteq \int\p{E}V⊆int(E).

    Next, we show that E‾\cl{E}E is a closed set. Let (x‾n)n=m∞\p{\cl{x}_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ be a sequence of elements in E‾\cl{E}E which converges to x0∈Ex_0 \in Ex0​∈E. We need to show that x0∈E‾x_0 \in \cl{E}x0​∈E, which means we need to find a sequence of elements in EEE which converges to x0x_0x0​. Since x‾n∈E‾\cl{x}_n \in \cl{E}xn​∈E, we know that for any r>0r > 0r>0, B(x‾,r)∩E≠∅B\p{\cl{x}, r} \cap E \neq \emptysetB(x,r)∩E=∅. In particular, if r=1nr = \frac{1}{n}r=n1​, then there exists xn∈Ex_n \in Exn​∈E such that xn∈B(x‾,1n)x_n \in B\p{\cl{x}, \frac{1}{n}}xn​∈B(x,n1​). The sequence (xn)n=m∞\p{x_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ also converges to x0x_0x0​:

    d(xn,x0)≤d(xn,x‾n)+d(x‾n,x0)≤1n+d(x‾n,x0).d\p{x_n, x_0} \leq d\p{x_n, \cl{x}_n} + d\p{\cl{x}_n, x_0} \leq \frac{1}{n} + d\p{\cl{x}_n, x_0}.d(xn​,x0​)≤d(xn​,xn​)+d(xn​,x0​)≤n1​+d(xn​,x0​).

    Sending n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞ (as we did in the proof of (iii)), the right-hand side tends to 000, so xn→n→∞x0x_n \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} x_0xn​n→∞​x0​. This shows that x0∈E‾x_0 \in \cl{E}x0​∈E, so E‾\cl{E}E is closed.

    Lastly, if KKK is a closed set such that K⊇EK \supseteq EK⊇E. Let x0∈E‾x_0 \in \cl{E}x0​∈E. Then there exists a sequence (xn)n=m∞\p{x_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ of elements in EEE such that xn→n→∞x0x_n \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} x_0xn​n→∞​x0​. But because E⊆KE \subseteq KE⊆K, this means (xn)n=m∞\p{x_n}_{n=m}^\infty(xn​)n=m∞​ is also a sequence of elements in KKK which converges to x0x_0x0​, so x0∈K‾=Kx_0 \in \cl{K} = Kx0​∈K=K. Thus, E‾⊆K\cl{E} \subseteq KE⊆K. □\square□
Remark.

It's important in (vi) (but not in (vii)) that the number of open/closed sets is finite. Here are two counter-examples from (R,∣ ⋅ ∣)\p{\R, \abs{\,\cdot\,}}(R,∣⋅∣).

  1. Let En=(−1n,1n)E_n = \p{-\frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{n}}En​=(−n1​,n1​). Then

    ⋂n=1∞En={0},\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty E_n = \set{0},n=1⋂∞​En​={0},

    which is not an open set. Indeed, these sets are equal since 0∈En0 \in E_n0∈En​ for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, and if x0∈⋂n=1∞Enx_0 \in \bigcap_{n=1}^\infty E_nx0​∈⋂n=1∞​En​, then x0x_0x0​ satisfies

    −1n<x0<1n  ⟺  ∣x0∣<1n.-\frac{1}{n} < x_0 < \frac{1}{n} \iff \abs{x_0} < \frac{1}{n}.−n1​<x0​<n1​⟺∣x0​∣<n1​.

    If x0≠0x_0 \neq 0x0​=0, then if n0n_0n0​ is large enough, we have ∣x0∣<1n0<∣x0∣\abs{x_0} < \frac{1}{n_0} < \abs{x_0}∣x0​∣<n0​1​<∣x0​∣, which is not possible. Thus, it must be the case that x0=0x_0 = 0x0​=0, which proves that the two sets above are equal.

    (Notice how I didn't mention that {0}\set{0}{0} is closed. In general, a set can be open, closed, both open and closed, or neither open nor closed. In other words, {0}\set{0}{0} being closed doesn't tell you whether or not it's open.)

  2. Fn=[−1+1n,1−1n]F_n = \br{-1 + \frac{1}{n}, 1 - \frac{1}{n}}Fn​=[−1+n1​,1−n1​] gives another counter-example (exercise below).
Exercise 1.

Let Fn=[−1+1n,1−1n]F_n = \br{-1 + \frac{1}{n}, 1 - \frac{1}{n}}Fn​=[−1+n1​,1−n1​]. Compute ⋃n=1∞Fn\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty F_n⋃n=1∞​Fn​ and show that it is not closed (which is not the same as showing that it's open).
